Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Statistical Estimation with Algebraic Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific and engineering disciplines ranging from structural biology to computer vision rely on data collection and analysis to guide scientific discovery. Critically, in such applications, the systems under study constrain and govern the structure of information in collected data. The goal of this research project is to develop a family of statistical models that enables a systematic extraction of relevant statistical information from these datasets by bringing together interdisciplinary concepts from statistics and optimization. The approach under development aims to provide a new set of statistical tools that is adapted to this class of problems and that could have a transformative impact on several scientific disciplines.

This project is articulated around a core set of techniques to analyze datasets in the context of a latent algebraic structure, often arising from the physical laws underlying the data collection processes. Unlike more traditional statistical problems where a linear underlying structure is often built into the model, data-driven science generates problems with algebraic but often non-linear structure. The project focuses on problems of central importance in a variety of scientific and engineering disciplines, including signal processing, structural biology, and computer vision, that share a similar feature: the need to leverage algebraic structure in order to extract information from data. The project aims at developing a systematic approach to analyze this family of problems, together with a general procedure to construct computationally efficient algorithms using low-rank tensor decomposition. Importantly, these methods can be proved to be statistically optimal and therefore make the most efficient use of collected data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data-driven methods are now central to scientific discovery. As a result, new, large and complex datasets are now routinely produced in most disciplines. Mining these datasets requires careful and tailored statistical approaches that employ specific domain knowledge as opposed to general-purpose machine learning techniques whose broad applicability comes in the way of efficient discovery.
The goal of this project was to develop such methods for several problems that are of central importance in science and engineering such as singal processing, structural biology, and computer vision. These problems share a common feature: the signal of interest obeys the rather rigid laws of physics and a careful inference framework was necessary to achieve statistical optimality.
By bringing diverse mathematical tools in algebra, analysis and geometry, including representation theory and optimal transport, these new methods have significantly improved the quality of estimation and prediction in various disciplines.
The proposed methods come with strong theoretical guarantees and can be clustered into three main groups:
1. Algebraic methods: we identified several problems where the quantity of interest is subject to specific algebraic rules that are governed by the laws of physics. A central example is motivated by cryo-electron microscopy, a technique that was the background of a recent Nobel prize in chemistry. In this application, the quantity of interest is the three-dimensional structure of a molecule and the algebraic rule is a random orientation of said molecule. By leveraging connections to theoretical representations of algebraic groups, we were able not only to assess the required the amount of data of required to reconstruct the signal (e.g., molecule) but also to devise new statistical methods that make optimal use of data. In other prominent examples, the algebraic structure of interest is a permutation. Such structure is pervasive to network data analysis, ranking problems, and problems where one needs to combine multiple datasets to reconstruct a global picture of the phenomenon of interest. For these problems, we have imported statistical and computational tools from optimal transport theory to solve problems that were previously out of reach. For example, such techniques were used to reconstruct cellular trajectories at unprecedented accuracy.
2. Geometric methods: this project has allowed us to uncover fruitful connections with the theory of optimal transport, which connects various part of mathematics such as anlysis and geometry. In the context of this project, it became very useful to exploit a certain geometry of data that can be represented as probability distributions. We have developed statistical methods and efficient algorithms using optimal transport at large scale in a variety of applications: uncoupled regression, sampling, and interpolation for example. In essence, optimal transport endows complex objects (images, shapes, datasets, etc.) with a geometric structure that allows not only to measure distance between these objects but also to combine them in an "average object" known as barycenter. This project has brought a new light on the role of geometry not only in our understanding of barycenters, but also in the design and implementation of efficient algorithms to compute them.
These results were published in 23 refereed articles or conferences, 5 pre-publications currently under review, and one submitted US Patent. Furthermore, the project has supported the training of several PhD students as well as the development of course materials.
